newsitem.title: CHINA: China warns of new silk price war in 1997.
newsitem.headline: China warns of new silk price war in 1997.

text.p: Chinese officials on Friday warned of a new round of silk price wars in 1997 due to rising prices of cocoons and silk reeling in late 1996.

The price of dry cocoons hit 45,600 yuan ($5,494) per tonne last November, up 29.8 percent from the same period of 1995 while the price of silk reeling was 160,100 yuan per tonne, up 10.4 percent, the Market Daily said.
The State Planning Commission had urged all small reeling and spinning firms to stop panic purchases of cocoons to prevent a new price war, a commission official said by telephone.
China planned to close all sub-standard reeling and spinning mills that use high-quality cocoons but produce poor-quality silk while state-owned mills were starved of cocoons, he said.
However, the official said such drastic measures touched on the interests of local governments and were therefore difficult to implement.
